Let me sketch the code:

#include <stdio.h>

int N;

int aaa(int current, int mask) {
    if (current > N) return 0;
    int count = ( mask & 0b111 ) == 0b111 ? 1 :0;  // if mask has all bits set → 7?

    int new_current;
    int new_mask;
    // for digits 7,5,3:
    for (int d : {7,5,3})  // C doesn't have loops like this, so need a loop with array or separate code for each digit
    // alternative:

    for each digit d in {7,5,3}:
        new_current = current *10 +d;
        new_mask = mask;
        if (d ==3) {
            new_mask |= 1;  // Set bit0
        } 
        else if (d ==5) {
            new_mask |= 2; // bit1
        }
        else if (d ==7){
            new_mask |=4; // bit2
        }
        count += aaa(new_current, new_mask);
    return count;
}

The code outline would be:

#include <stdio.h>

int N;

int aaa(int current, int mask) {
    if (current > N)
        return 0;
    int has_all = (mask & 0x7) == 0x7;  // 0x7 is 0b111
    int count = has_all ? 1 : 0;

    // Now try adding 7,5,3 to current (current *10 + each)
    int digits[3] = {7,5,3};
    for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
        int digit = digits[i];
        int new_curr = current *10 + digit;
        int new_mask = mask; 
        if (digit == 3) {
            new_mask |= 1; // 0th bit for 3
        } else if (digit ==5) {
            new_mask |= 2; //1st bit for5
        } else if (digit ==7) {
            new_mask |= 4; //2nd bit for7
        }
        count += aaa(new_curr, new_mask);
    }
    return count;
}

int main() {
    scanf("%d", &N);
    printf("%d\n", aaa(0,0));
    return 0;
}
